hawaiian_text: Iā lāua e noho ana, iho maila ‘o Puali‘i, he  kanaka maika‘i no Līhu‘e, i ka lawai‘a ma kai o  Honouliuli, kipa maila ia ma ka hale o Pōka‘ī. Nānā  akula ‘o Puali‘i iā Pōka‘ī a makemake akula iā ia,  ‘ōlelo akula ia: “Makemake au iā ‘oe i wahine  na‘u.” ‘Ī mai ‘o Pōka‘ī: “Pehea ‘oe e makemake ai  ia‘u? Ua hānau wau i ke keiki, a ua ‘ino‘ino ko‘u  kino.” ‘Ī aku ‘o Puali‘i: “He mea ‘ole ia mau mea, ke  makemake ‘oe ia‘u, e moe kāua.”‘Ae akula ‘o  Pōka‘ī. A ho‘i akula ‘o Pōka‘ī me kāna kāne me  Puali‘i ā ke kula o Keahumoa, noho.
gpt-4_1-mini_translation: While the two were sitting, down came Puali‘i, a good man from Līhu‘e, fishing at sea off Honouliuli, who then visited the house of Pōka‘i. Puali‘i looked upon Pōka‘i and desired her, saying: “I want you for my wife.” Pōka‘i replied: “How can you desire me? I have borne a child, and my body is blemished.” Puali‘i answered: “These things are nothing; if you want me, we shall be together.” Pōka‘i consented. Then Pōka‘i returned with her husband to Puali‘i at the district of Keahumoa and lived there.
gpt-4_1-mini_commentary:
• Allegorical reading of relationships and desire:
  – Puali‘i’s approach to Pōka‘i symbolizes social or spiritual desire that transcends conventional stigma. Pōka‘i’s hesitance due to having borne a child and feeling bodily imperfection suggests cultural ideas about purity or status, possibly reflecting Hawaiian notions of kapu related to women’s fertility and sexuality (Kameʻeleihiwa, 1992).
  – Puali‘i’s reassurance that those conditions “are nothing” may allegorically critique rigid kapu or social barriers, demonstrating a transition period in Hawaiian society as traditional restrictions were questioned or softened, especially post-Ai Kapu abandonment in 1819.

• Analysis of character names and symbolism:
  – Puali‘i (Pua-li‘i) can be broken down as “Pua” (flower; youth or beauty) and “li‘i” (chiefly or small/young), representing perhaps a youthful, noble figure embodying renewal or new social ideals.
  – Pōka‘i is “Pō” (night, dark, mystery) plus “ka‘i” (to lead, to escort); this may symbolize a female figure connected with mystery or the unconscious, leading or guiding in a subtle way—her initial rejection and later consent represent transformative potential.
  – The place names also bear significance: Līhu‘e (“spread wings”) and Honouliuli (a coastal area known for fishing) point to livelihood and connection to nature, fitting Puali‘i’s role as a fisherman and provider.

• Historical and cultural contextualization:
  – The passage hints at social dynamics in Kaua‘i during early 19th century, a time when missionary presence and changing cultural norms led to reevaluation of familial and marital structures (Silva, 2004).
  – Pōka‘i’s statement about her body being “blemished” after childbirth might metaphorically reflect the shift from traditional kapu systems concerning women’s reproductive roles, highlighting tensions caused by Western influence on Hawaiian cultural and gender expectations.
  – The narrative’s willingness to affirm sexual union despite past childbearing may indirectly reflect post-contact Hawaiian society’s evolving attitudes toward women’s sexuality and the erosion of strict kapu in the post-1820 period.

• Broader thematic connections:
  – Numerically, the dialogue involves a dyad of male-female figures negotiating social boundaries, perhaps echoing traditional Hawaiian concepts of duality and balance (kānaka and wāhine, mana and noa).
  – The emphasis on place and movement (Pōka‘i returning “to Puali‘i at Keahumoa”) underscores Hawaiian values of ‘āina (land) as foundation of identity and social relationship.
  – This passage may serve as subtle social commentary on reconciliation and acceptance amidst shifting mores, reflecting a cultural moment when Hawaiian society negotiated between tradition and new realities.

References:  
Kameʻeleihiwa, L. (1992). Native Land and Foreign Desires: Pehea Lā E Pono Ai? Bishop Museum Press.  
Silva, N. K. (2004). Aloha Betrayed: Native Hawaiian Resistance to American Colonialism. Duke University Press.

reference_translation: The two were going about their life when Puali‘i,  a good man, arrived from inland in Līhu‘e, to go  fishing on the shore of Honouliuli. He paid a visit to  the home of Pōka‘ī and looked at her and liked  her. He said, “I’d like you to be my woman.” Pōka‘ī  replied, “How could you possibly want me? I’ve  given birth to a child and my body is ruined.”  Puali‘i said, “I don’t care about that. If you like me,  let’s sleep together.” Pōka‘ī agreed and she went  with Puali‘i, now her man, to the plains of  Keahumoa to live.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 3:**• A new character is introduced, Pua-(a)li‘i  (child/descendant of a chief/chiefly line), described  as a good man, arrived from inland at Līhu‘e  (Wāhiāwā), to go fishing at Hono-uliuli (dark bay) in  ‘Ewa, somewhere in the area where Pō-ka-‘ī was  living with her baby, Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o.  – In the ‘Ai Kapu era, everyone walked on land to  every destination and it was normal to call in to the  house of strangers and ask for food and water. It  was normal to receive strangers at one’s home and  provide them with food and water, and it was  considered rude to refuse generosity. This is a  custom recounted in many stories. This is likely the  reason Pua-li‘i called in at Pōka‘ī’s house and why  Pōka‘ī received Pua-li‘i in her home, where he  observed how she was living;  • Pua-li‘i falls in love with Pō-ka-‘ī and proposes a  longterm relationship. Pō-ka-‘ī expresses hesitation  due to a negative self-image, but Pua-li‘i reassures her that as long as they both like each other, the two should begin a longterm relationship and   acknowledge each other as ʻkāne’ (boyfriend,  husband, longterm lover) and ʻwahine’ (girlfriend,  wife, longterm lover). The couple relocate to Ke-ahu moa (heap of chickens) in Līhu‘e (Wāhiāwā), where  Pua-li‘i is from, to live;  • It seems the meal Pua-li‘i proposed, with the cooked  head of ulua and sweet potatoes, was a kind of ‘Ai  Kapu ritual meal perhaps solidifying/formalizing their  longterm relationship;
